statement.text: Intraoperative bowel viability assessment remains one of the most challenging aspects of mesenteric ischemia surgery, requiring integration of clinical signs (color, peristalsis, bleeding), adjunctive technologies (fluorescein, Doppler), and surgical judgment to distinguish reversibly ischemic from irreversibly necrotic bowel, with second-look laparotomy serving as a critical safety net.
statement.formal: Viability Assessment: Visual inspection + Palpation + Doppler signals + Adjuncts (fluorescein/ICG) + Time for reperfusion â†’ Viable (observe) OR Nonviable (resect) OR Indeterminate (second-look)

explanation.intuition: Assessing bowel viability is like trying to determine if a wilted plant is salvageable or dead. A plant that's drooping from lack of water might recover once watered, but one whose roots have rotted will not. Similarly, bowel that looks dark from temporary blood deprivation may pink up after revascularization, while truly necrotic bowel is dead regardless of blood flow restoration.
explanation.key_insight: No single test can definitively distinguish ischemic from necrotic bowel at the time of surgery. Even the best clinical judgment has a 10-20% error rate. This uncertainty is why the second-look laparotomy was developed - a planned return in 24-48 hours to reassess questionable segments after giving reperfusion time to declare whether bowel will survive.
explanation.technical_details: The bowel's survival depends on the depth and duration of ischemia. Mucosal ischemia may recover completely, while transmural necrosis will not. The challenge is that transmural necrosis may not be apparent at the time of initial surgery, especially in the setting of reperfusion. Waiting 15-30 minutes after revascularization before making final resection decisions is standard practice.

signs_of_viability: Pink or red color (especially after revascularization)
Absence of grey or green discoloration
signs_of_nonviability: Absence of any color change after revascularization

palpation_and_motility.viable: Palpable mesenteric arterial pulses, visible peristalsis, normal wall thickness
palpation_and_motility.nonviable: Absent pulses, no peristalsis, thin or doughy wall
palpation_and_motility.warming: Apply warm saline-soaked packs and wait 15-30 minutes before final judgment

bleeding_test.technique: Small cut or needle puncture in antimesenteric border
bleeding_test.nonviable: Dark, venous blood or no bleeding

doppler_ultrasound.technique: Handheld continuous-wave Doppler probe on mesenteric arcade and bowel wall

interpretation.viable: Arterial signals in mesentery and antimesenteric border

doppler_ultrasound.limitations: Cannot assess mucosal perfusion, artifact from adjacent vessels

fluorescein_angiography.technique: IV fluorescein (10-15 mL of 10%), examination under Wood's lamp
fluorescein_angiography.limitations: Low specificity, false positives (edematous bowel), anaphylaxis risk

ICG_angiography.technique: IV indocyanine green, near-infrared fluorescence imaging system

interpretation.viable: Uniform fluorescent signal on bowel wall

ICG_angiography.advantages: Real-time, quantifiable, can assess perfusion dynamically

pulse_oximetry.technique: Reflectance pulse oximeter probe placed on bowel serosa
pulse_oximetry.limitations: Limited by motion artifact, not widely adopted

laser_doppler_flowmetry.technique: Laser probe measures microvascular blood flow

second_look_laparotomy.definition: Planned re-exploration 24-48 hours after initial surgery to reassess bowel viability
indications: Questionable bowel viability at initial surgery
Massive resection with borderline remaining bowel
Damage control surgery with temporary closure

technique.assessment: Re-examine all bowel, especially margins of prior resection
technique.decision: Resect any newly apparent necrosis, consider anastomosis if stable

outcomes.recommendation: Low threshold to plan second-look in uncertain cases

second_look_laparotomy.dilemma_in_practice: Some surgeons advocate mandatory second-look for all AMI; others use selective approach based on intraoperative findings

clear_cut_cases.obviously_necrotic: Resect with 2-3 cm margins into healthy tissue

questionable_cases.approach_1: Resect questionable segment, primary anastomosis, second-look
questionable_cases.approach_2: Preserve questionable segment, plan obligatory second-look
questionable_cases.approach_3: Resect with stoma, assess stability before anastomosis

margin_selection.technique: Cut incrementally until brisk arterial bleeding seen
margin_selection.balance: Minimize resection to preserve bowel length vs. leaving ischemic tissue

over_resection.cause: Excessive caution, removing potentially viable bowel

sources.citation: Defined review on bowel viability assessment techniques

learning_objectives: Describe clinical and adjunctive methods for assessing bowel viability
Understand the role and timing of second-look laparotomy
Recognize the limitations of all assessment methods
Apply a systematic approach to resection decisions
clinical_pearls: No test is 100% - when in doubt, second-look
Wait 15-30 minutes after revascularization before deciding
ICG angiography is the best adjunct if available
Better to second-look unnecessarily than to miss progressive necrosis
